Here is an example of how you could use R to forecast GDP using a time series analysis and the ARIMA model:
```
# First, install and load the necessary libraries
install.packages("forecast")
library(forecast)

# Next, import the GDP data and create a time series object
gdp_data <- read.csv("gdp_data.csv")
gdp_ts <- ts(gdp_data$value, start = c(year(gdp_data$date[1]), quarter(gdp_data$date[1])), frequency = 4)

# Check for stationarity
adf.test(gdp_ts)
kpss.test(gdp_ts)

# If the data is non-stationary, difference the data to make it stationary
gdp_ts_diff <- diff(gdp_ts)

# Use the auto.arima function to select the best ARIMA model
best_model <- auto.arima(gdp_ts_diff)

# Use the selected model to forecast future GDP values
forecast_horizon <- 5
forecast_gdp <- forecast(best_model, h=forecast_horizon)
plot(forecast_gdp)
```
In this example, the GDP data is imported and a time series object is created using the "ts" function. The GDP data is then checked for stationarity using the "adf.test" and "kpss.test" functions. If the data is non-stationary, it is differenced to make it stationary.

The "auto.arima" function is then used to select the best ARIMA model for the stationary GDP data. Finally, the selected model is used to forecast future GDP values for the next 5 years.

This is a basic example, for more robust forecast you can consider including exogenous variables, feature engineering, and also evaluate the model performance with different evaluation metric before interpreting the results.
It's worth noting that, this is just a code snippet, you need to have the GDP data and also make sure that you have the required packages installed in your R environment.
